skill.name: agent-browser
skill.description:
Browser automation for AI agents via inference.sh.
Navigate web pages, interact with elements using @e refs, take screenshots, record video.
Capabilities: web scraping, form filling, clicking, typing, drag-drop, file upload, JavaScript execution.
Use for: web automation, data extraction, testing, agent browsing, research.
Triggers: browser, web automation, scrape, navigate, click, fill form, screenshot,
browse web, playwright, headless browser, web agent, surf internet, record video
skill.summary:
Browser automation for AI agents via inference.sh.
Navigate web pages, interact with elements using ...
skill.author: inferencesh

security_audit.summary: This is a browser automation skill that requires shell execution and network access for legitimate functionality. The tool uses shell commands to control browsers, which is expected for a browser automation skill. All network URLs are for legitimate browser automation targets, not data exfiltration. The heuristic findings are "false" positives - the skill performs legitimate automation operations, not malicious activities.

high_findings.title: High Complexity Shell Operations
high_findings.description: Shell commands are extensively used for browser automation, requiring careful review of command inputs

medium_findings.title: User Input Passing to Shell
medium_findings.description: User-provided inputs may be passed to shell commands without explicit validation

low_findings.title: Hardcoded URLs
low_findings.description: Several URLs are hardcoded in configuration and documentation files

low_findings.title: Path Traversal Patterns
low_findings.description: Path traversal patterns detected in documentation examples

content.value_statement: This skill automates web browser interactions through Claude. It handles navigation, form filling, data extraction, and task workflows without manual clicks or typing. Perfect for research, testing, and repetitive web-based tasks.
actual_capabilities: Navigate to web pages and extract structured data
Fill forms automatically with pre-configured data
Click elements, drag and drop items
limitations: Limited to browsers supported by underlying automation library
No support for dynamic AJAX-heavy applications without JavaScript execution
Slow for extremely large-scale scraping operations
Blocked by some sophisticated CAPTCHA systems
Not suitable for real-time interactive browsing

use_cases.title: Automate Web Research
use_cases.description: Research teams use this skill to systematically gather data from multiple websites. It automates repetitive data entry and extraction tasks, allowing researchers to process large datasets efficiently.

use_cases.title: Test Web Applications
use_cases.description: QA teams automate testing workflows by navigating through applications, filling forms, and verifying functionality. This reduces manual testing time and catches regressions early.

use_cases.title: Collect Product Information
use_cases.description: E-commerce and marketing teams scrape product information from competitor sites, monitor price changes, and gather competitive intelligence automatically.

prompt_templates.title: Beginner: Simple Data Extraction
prompt_templates.prompt: Navigate to https://example.com/products and extract the product names and prices from the first page. Return the data as a JSON list.
prompt_templates.scenario: First time user needs to extract basic product information

prompt_templates.title: Intermediate: Form Filling and Submission
prompt_templates.prompt: Navigate to https://example.com/contact and fill in the form with: Name: John Doe, Email: john@example.com, Message: Please send me more information. Submit the form and confirm it was successful.
prompt_templates.scenario: User needs to fill out a contact form automatically

prompt_templates.title: Advanced: Authentication and Data Retrieval
prompt_templates.prompt: Navigate to https://example.com/login and authenticate with username: myuser and password: mypass123. Once logged in, navigate to the /dashboard page and extract all the data displayed there. Return the results in a structured format.
prompt_templates.scenario: User needs to work with authenticated web applications

prompt_templates.title: Expert: Complex Workflow Automation
prompt_templates.prompt:
1. Navigate to https://example.com/search and search for 'javascript tutorials'.
2. Extract titles and links from the first 10 results.
3. For each link, navigate to it and extract the main content.
4. Compile all extracted content into a single markdown document with proper headings.
5. Take a screenshot of the final results page.
prompt_templates.scenario: Advanced user needs to perform multi-step automated research

output_examples.input: Navigate to https://example.com/products and extract product names and prices
output_examples.output:
Successfully navigated to https://example.com/products.

Extracted product data:

```json
[
  {
    \"name\": \"Product Alpha\",
    \"price\": \"$29.99\",
    \"link\": \"/products/alpha\"
  },
  {
    \"name\": \"Product Beta\",
    \"price\": \"$49.99\",
    \"link\": \"/products/beta\"
  }
]
```

Screenshot saved: products.png

output_examples.input: Fill out the contact form and submit it
output_examples.output:
Successfully navigated to https://example.com/contact.

Form filled with:
- Name: John Doe
- Email: john@example.com
- Message: Please send me more information

Form submitted successfully. Confirmation message displayed: 'Thank you for your message, John!'

best_practices: Always test automation workflows with small data sets first
Configure browser user agents to avoid detection by some websites
Implement proper delays between actions to simulate human behavior
Save screenshots or videos for debugging complex workflows
Validate extracted data before processing to catch parsing errors
Use session management for authenticated workflows to maintain state
Clear browser cache before starting new automation sessions
Monitor browser console for errors that might indicate problems
anti_patterns: Don't automate without first understanding the target website's terms of service
Avoid filling forms with excessive data or at high speed - this triggers captchas
Never pass sensitive credentials in plain text without proper security considerations
Don't ignore error messages - they indicate problems with the automation
Avoid scraping without checking for robots.txt files on target sites
Don't ignore rate limits - excessive requests will get you blocked
Avoid hardcoding credentials in scripts - use environment variables instead

faq.question: What browsers does this skill support?
faq.answer: This skill supports browsers that the underlying automation library (Playwright) can control, including Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge. You can specify which browser to use in your requests.

faq.question: Can I handle authentication with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, this skill provides templates for authenticated sessions. You can configure credentials and the skill will handle login, session management, and data retrieval while maintaining authentication state.

faq.question: Will this skill help with CAPTCHA challenges?
faq.answer: This skill can handle basic CAPTCHAs but not advanced ones. For sites with complex CAPTCHAs, you may need to manually complete them or use a separate CAPTCHA-solving service.

faq.question: How do I handle dynamic content loading?
faq.answer: The skill includes JavaScript execution capabilities. You can wait for dynamic content to load by using waits or checking for element visibility before proceeding with extraction.

faq.question: Can I record videos of automation sessions?
faq.answer: Yes, this skill supports video recording. You can request video capture of your automation sessions for debugging or demonstration purposes.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: All data processing happens locally or in the browser context. Your credentials and data are handled according to the skill's documented practices. Avoid entering sensitive information into test forms.
